results.title: The Gods of Tiny Things
results.credit_line:
Deborah Kelly

Two-channel digital animation, colour, sound

ACMI Collection

Collage figures: Joanne Albany, Alana Ambados, Kate Andrews, Justin Ashworth, Kathryn Bird, Karen Golland, Amanda Holt, Deborah Kelly, Kath Lim, Lex Lindsay, Megan Rushton, Rie Tamaoke, Anna Tregloan
results.brief_description: Deborah Kelly’s The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopaedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies.

constellations_primary.name: Speculative futures, sci-fi worlds and environmental disaster
constellations_primary.description: Deborah Kelly's The Gods of Tiny Things explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world through collage and imagined futures, much like these sci-fi, animated and computer-generated artworks.

results.description:
“This work is blessed by the powers of the animator, musicians and collagists. Having such creative collaborators is the treasure of my life.” – Deborah Kelly

The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life. Created at ‘collage camp’ at Bundanon on beautiful Yuin Country, this collaborative work is a poetic and urgent warning.

Deborah Kelly is a Sydney-based artist whose works have been shown around Australia, and in the Biennales of Singapore, Sydney, Thessaloniki, TarraWarra and Venice. Her projects across media are concerned with lineages of representation, politics and history in public exchange, and practices of collectivity on small and large scale, both fleeting and durational. Her newest works experiment with models of sustained creative collaboration between strangers. Kelly’s moving image artworks have been shown around the world, in galleries, cinemas and projected onto rock formations, buildings and clouds.
description_for_label: The Gods of Tiny Things is a vast, microscopic Eden teeming with deities born from the pages of old magazines and encyclopedias, creating an exquisite collage of grotesque beauty and new mythologies. Combining the divine, mundane and profane, these celestial creations animate a kaleidoscopic symbology that explores extinction and the climate crisis, the scars of colonialism, and the political shift to the right around the world, while simultaneously revelling in the persistence of pleasure, desire and life.

results.title: The Gold Rush (1925)
results.brief_description: The Gold Rush, an immortal classic, is regarded as one of Chaplin’s very best films, interweaving to brilliant effect the pathetic tale of the Tramp’s apparently hopeless love for a dancehall girl with the funny story of the Tramp and his burly gold prospecting partner heading off to make their fortunes in the great Yukon gold rush. Through the entire film hangs Chaplin’s finely perceived view of the contrast between the Tramp’s selfless, humanitarian behaviour, and the unpleasant, brutish life of the gold town society. Rated: G
results.description: The Gold Rush, an immortal classic, is regarded as one of Chaplin’s very best films, interweaving to brilliant effect the pathetic tale of the Tramp’s apparently hopeless love for a dancehall girl with the funny story of the Tramp and his burly gold prospecting partner heading off to make their fortunes in the great Yukon gold rush. Through the entire film hangs Chaplin’s finely perceived view of the contrast between the Tramp’s selfless, humanitarian behaviour, and the unpleasant, brutish life of the gold town society. Rated: G

results.creator_credit: Michelle Tobin and ACMI Digital Storytelling

results.title: The Giving tree
results.creator_credit: Charlie O. Hayward, Nick Bosustow, Shel Silverstein and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: This poignant story about the relationships between a boy and a tree illustrates some truths about the meaning of giving, receiving and love. the tree unselfishly offers itself to the boy for climbing, for shade and for pleasure. But as the boy grows up his life takes him further and further away from the tree. But old age brings their relationship full circle. Based on the book by Shel Silverstein. Music and narration by Shel Silverstein. Animation by Charlie O. Hayward.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Charlie O. Hayward, Nick Bosustow, Shel Silverstein and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.description: This poignant story about the relationships between a boy and a tree illustrates some truths about the meaning of giving, receiving and love. the tree unselfishly offers itself to the boy for climbing, for shade and for pleasure. Music and narration by Shel Silverstein. Animation by Charlie O. Hayward.

results.title: The Glacier climbers
results.brief_description: The story of a four day mountain journey from Westland to Canterbury across the Southern Alps. At Malte Brun Hut the climbers meet Sir Edmund Hillary and the parties combine for the last stage of the journey down the Tasman Glacier to the Hermitage, Mount Cook. Includes some spectacular mountain scenes.
results.description: The story of a four day mountain journey from Westland to Canterbury across the Southern Alps. At Malte Brun Hut the climbers meet Sir Edmund Hillary and the parties combine for the last stage of the journey down the Tasman Glacier to the Hermitage, Mount Cook. Includes some spectacular mountain scenes.

results.title: A Short story about love
results.creator_credit: Karen Wootton and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Karen is young, travelling and in love. When she returns from her travels she discovers she has HIV and with this diagnosis her life changes. Karen must come to terms with life’s new circumstances as she laments the fact that she may never have another relationship or be a mother. But life does move on for Karen and with the help of friends and family, Karen finds love again.

results.title: The Giving tree
results.creator_credit: Charlie O. Hayward, Nick Bosustow, Shel Silverstein and Stephen Bosustow Productions
results.brief_description: This poignant story about the relationships between a boy and a tree illustrates some truths about the meaning of giving, receiving and love. The tree unselfishly offers itself to the boy for climbing, for shade and for pleasure. But as the boy grows up his life takes him further and further away from the tree. But old age brings their relationship full circle. Based on the book by Shel Silverstein. Music and narration by Shel Silverstein. Animation by Charlie O. Hayward.

The tree unselfishly offers itself to the boy for climbing, for shade and for pleasure. But as the boy grows up his life takes him further and further away from the tree. But old age brings their relationship full circle. Based on the book by Shel Silverstein. Music and narration by Shel Silverstein. Animation by Charlie O. Hayward.
